skills.name: Given information about one part, work out the whole
Given information about one part, work out other parts
Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out the whole
Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out other parts

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have just added the '2' from the bike part of the ratio on to the 70 cars. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 70 cars is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.
explanations.B: There are 5 parts to the car bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 70 ÷ 5 = 14. The bike side of our ratio has 2 parts to it, therefore 2 × 14 = 28 bikes. Therefore in total there are 70 cars + 28 bikes = 98 Vehicles
explanations.C: Dividing 70 by 7 will not find one part of the ratio as 70 represents the number of cars NOT the total number of vehicles. How many parts of the ratio represents 'cars'? Use this to find out what one part of the ratio is worth and therefore how many bikes there are.
explanations.D: Not quite! This is the number of bikes, the question asks for the TOTAL number of vehicles...

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have just added the '3' from the van part of the ratio on to the 80 cars. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 80 cars is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.
explanations.B: Not quite! This is the number of vans, the question asks for the TOTAL number of vehicles...
explanations.C: There are 5 parts to the car bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 80 ÷ 5 = 16. The van side of our ratio has 3 parts to it, therefore 3 × 16 = 48 vans. Therefore in total there are 80 cars + 48 vans = 128 Vehicles
explanations.D: Dividing 80 by 8 will not find one part of the ratio as 80 represents the number of cars NOT the total number of vehicles. How many parts of the ratio represents 'cars'? Use this to find out what one part of the ratio is worth and therefore how many bikes there are.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have confused which part of the ratio is for cars and which for bikes. Remember, the ratio is shown in the same order as it is written in words.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have simply subtracted the difference between the parts of the ratio. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 70 cars is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 70 into 7 equal parts. The 70 cars is only one part of the ratio though, start by thinking which part and what this means for the bike part of the ratio.
explanations.D: There are 5 parts to the car bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 70 ÷ 5 = 14. The bike side of our ratio has 2 parts to it, therefore 2 × 14 = 28 bikes.

explanations.A: There are 4 parts to the car bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 60 ÷ 4 = 15. The vans side of our ratio has 3 parts to it, therefore 3 × 15 = 45 vans.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have given us the total number of vehicles rather than the total number of vans only. Which part of the ratio represents the vans?
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have confused which part of the ratio is for cars and which for bikes. Remember, the ratio is shown in the same order as it is written in words.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have simply subtracted the difference between the parts of the ratio. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 60 cars is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.

explanations.A: There are 2 parts to the bike bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 70 ÷ 2 = 35. The car side of our ratio has 5 parts to it, therefore 5 × 35 = 175 cars.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have simply added the difference between the parts of the ratio. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 70 bikes is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 70 into 7 equal parts. The 70 bikes is only one part of the ratio though, start by thinking which part and what this means for the car part of the ratio.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have confused which part of the ratio is for cars and which for bikes. Remember, the ratio is shown in the same order as it is written in words.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have simply added the difference between the parts of the ratio. Start by thinking how many parts of the ratio the 120 vans is represented by, and therefore what 1 part of the ratio would be worth.
explanations.B: There are 3 parts to the van bit of our ratio, therefore 1 part of the ratio is worth 120 ÷ 3 = 40. The cars side of our ratio has 5 parts to it, therefore 5 × 40 = 200 cars.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 120 into 8 equal parts. The 120 vans is only one part of the ratio though, start by thinking which part and what this means for the car part of the ratio.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have confused which part of the ratio is for cars and which for vans. Remember, the ratio is shown in the same order as it is written in words.

explanations.A: Not Quite! I think you have multiplied 210 by 7, the number of parts in the ratio. However 210 is how many MORE cars than bikes there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the bike bit.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 210 into 7 equal parts, as there are 7 parts to the ratio overall. However 210 is how many MORE cars than bikes there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the bike bit.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 210 into 5 equal parts. 210 is not the total number of cars though, it's how many MORE cars than bikes there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the bike bit.
explanations.D: There are 3 extra 'parts' to the car part of the ratio vs the bike part. If these 3 parts are worth 210, one part of the ratio is worth 210 ÷ 3 = 70. There are 7 parts to the ratio altogether, each worth 70 vehicles, therefore there are 7 × 70 = 490 vehicles in total

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 120 into 8 equal parts, as there are 8 parts to the ratio overall. However 120 is how many MORE cars than vans there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the van bit.
explanations.B: Not Quite! I think you have multiplied 120 by 8, the number of parts in the ratio. However 120 is how many MORE cars than vans there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the van bit.
explanations.C: There are 2 extra 'parts' to the car part of the ratio vs the van part. If these 2 parts are worth 120, one part of the ratio is worth 120 ÷ 2 = 60. There are 8 parts to the ratio altogether, each worth 60 vehicles, therefore there are 8 × 60 = 480 vehicles in total
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 120 into 8 equal parts. 120 is not the total number of vehicles though, it's how many MORE cars than vans there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the van bit.

explanations.A: Not quite! You have used 210 as one part in the ratio, but 210 is the difference between cars and bikes. Check the ratio, how many parts is that?
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 210 into 5 equal parts. 210 is not the total number of cars, it's how many MORE cars than bikes there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the bike bit.
explanations.C: There are 3 extra 'parts' to the car part of the ratio vs the bike part. If these 3 parts are worth 210, one part of the ratio is worth 210 ÷ 3 = 70. There are 2 parts to the bike bit of the ratio altogether, each worth 70 vehicles, therefore there are 2 × 70 = 140 bikes in total
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you have worked out the total number of vehicles here, whereas the question asks for the number of bikes only.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have worked out the total number of vehicles here, whereas the question asks for the number of vans only.
explanations.B: Not quite! You have used 120 as one part in the ratio, but 120 is the difference between cars and vans. Check the ratio, how many parts is that?
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have worked out what each part of the ratio is worth based on dividing 120 into 5 equal parts. 120 is not the total number of cars though, it's how many MORE cars than vans there are. Start by thinking how many more parts there is to the car bit of the ratio vs the van bit.
explanations.D: There are 2 extra 'parts' to the car part of the ratio vs the van part. If these 2 parts are worth 120, one part of the ratio is worth 120 ÷ 2 = 60. There are 3 parts to the van bit of the ratio, each worth 60 vehicles, therefore there are 3 × 60 = 180 vans in total
